dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so today, we're diving into Bitcoin. I mean, everyone's heard of it, right? It's supposed to be this, like, revolutionary decentralized currency.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so today, we're diving into Bitcoin. I mean, everyone's heard of it, right? It's supposed to be this, like, revolutionary decentralized currency.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, you'd think so, wouldn't you? But, uh, the article we looked at paints a pretty different picture. It suggests Bitcoin isn't actually as decentralized as people believe.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, you'd think so, wouldn't you? But, uh, the article we looked at paints a pretty different picture. It suggests Bitcoin isn't actually as decentralized as people believe.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bitcoin is a unique monetary asset in that it is free from the control of any central bank and doesnt need to be audited by a third party to ensure its value. It is instead tracked and verified by thousands of computers on a shared network that is called a blockchain, which uses cryptography to reach consensus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Really? So, it's not this wild west of digital money?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Really? So, it's not this wild west of digital money?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Not exactly. It's tracked and verified by, quote, "a select few computers on a private network." And apparently, its underlying technology, um, has proven pretty incapable of improving finance.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Not exactly. It's tracked and verified by, quote, a select few computers on a private network. And apparently, its underlying technology, um, has proven pretty incapable of improving finance.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is instead tracked and verified by thousands of computers on a shared network that is called a blockchain... Bitcoins underlying distributed ledger technology has the potential to not only dramatically overhaul finance...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Huh. So, all those big promises about changing property ownership or healthcare, that's just... fluff?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh. So, all those big promises about changing property ownership or healthcare, that's just... fluff?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. The article says it had "negligible effects" on those fields. No big revolution there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. The article says it had negligible effects on those fields. No big revolution there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bitcoins underlying distributed ledger technology has the potential to not only dramatically overhaul finance, but also fields ranging from property ownership to health care and voting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but what about its origin? Satoshi Nakamoto, the mysterious creator?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but what about its origin? Satoshi Nakamoto, the mysterious creator?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And in the very first block of code, the "Genesis block," Nakamoto actually hid a headline from a British newspaper.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And in the very first block of code, the Genesis block, Nakamoto actually hid a headline from a British newspaper.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Buried within the code of his Genesis block, Nakamoto embedded a reminder of what happens when too much trust is placed in banks. It was a headline from a British newspaper...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, the one about the banks needing another bailout?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, the one about the banks needing another bailout?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! "Chancellor On Brink of Second Bailout for Banks." It was a subtle, uh, jab at the traditional financial system.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Chancellor On Brink of Second Bailout for Banks. It was a subtle, uh, jab at the traditional financial system.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It was a headline from a British newspaper announcing the imminent bailout of the financial institutions following their collapse in 2008 and 2009: The Times 03/Jan/2009 Chancellor On Brink of Second Bailout for Banks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, initially, it was super popular, right? Like, Wall Street bankers were into it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, initially, it was super popular, right? Like, Wall Street bankers were into it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For the first five years or so, bitcoin largely went unnoticed, appealing to a fringe group of programmers and libertarian idealists.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. For the first five years or so, it appealed to everyone. But then, as people understood the limitations of blockchain, things changed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. For the first five years or so, it appealed to everyone. But then, as people understood the limitations of blockchain, things changed.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For the first five years or so, bitcoin largely went unnoticed, appealing to a fringe group of programmers and libertarian idealists.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] And then came all the drama, like Silk Road and Mt. Gox.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then came all the drama, like Silk Road and Mt. Gox.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The nascent technology has been plagued by infamous scandals like the FBIs shuttering of underground bitcoin-fueled drug and contraband marketplace Silk Road in 2013 and the $450 million hacking of cryptocurrency exchange Mt. Gox in 2014.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the FBI shutting down Silk Road, Mt. Gox losing like, what, $460 million? Bitcoin's downfall, the article says, has been "consistent and stable."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the F B I shutting down Silk Road, Mt. Gox losing like, what, four hundred sixty million dollars? Bitcoin's downfall, the article says, has been consistent and stable.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The ascendance of bitcoin has not been without its setbacks. The nascent technology has been plagued by infamous scandals...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. And that huge bubble in 2017, where it hit, like, twenty grand?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. And that huge bubble in twenty seventeen, where it hit, like, twenty grand?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the end of 2017, the frenzy in cryptocurrency speculation peaked with bitcoin at $20,000 and produced thousands of worthless cryptocurrency tokens and investor losses in the billions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It bottomed out. Eliminated thousands of worthless tokens and billions in investor gains. All those idealistic visions kinda evaporated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It bottomed out. Eliminated thousands of worthless tokens and billions in investor gains. All those idealistic visions kinda evaporated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the end of 2017, the frenzy in cryptocurrency speculation peaked with bitcoin at $20,000 and produced thousands of worthless cryptocurrency tokens and investor losses in the billions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, even the big players who dismissed it initially are getting involved now?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, even the big players who dismissed it initially are getting involved now?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's the real twist! Companies like JPMorgan and IBM, who were super dismissive, are now, uh, looking at blockchain software for enterprises.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's the real twist! Companies like J P Morgan and I B M, who were super dismissive, are now, uh, looking at blockchain software for enterprises.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact in a bit cruel irony, some of the most enthusiastic supporters and co-opters of blockchain technology today are those same big companies, ranging from IBM and Cargill to JPMorgan, that early bitcoin believers were rallying against.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, in the end, it's less of a revolution and more... just another asset with a bumpy ride?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, in the end, it's less of a revolution and more... just another asset with a bumpy ride?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. It's unique, but maybe not the disruptive force everyone hoped for.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. It's unique, but maybe not the disruptive force everyone hoped for.
